bestBHT.bht: After passionately arguing his point in the previous chapter, Paul now addresses his readers as brethren and expresses his strong affection and desire for the salvation of Israel. Despite the severity of his previous argument, he wants to dispel any doubts about his love for his own people. His heartfelt prayer and supplication to God on their behalf demonstrate the genuine goodwill and satisfaction of his heart. Paul's unwavering commitment to intercede for the salvation of his kinsmen is evident as he continually lifts them up in prayer before the throne of grace.

Henry Alford: now, as if the severity of the preceding argument were passed over, he affectionately addresses them as brethren.
the inclination (or, desire) of my heart and my supplication to God on their behalf (Israel)
The Apostle’s intention seems to be, to destroy any impression which his readers may have received un-favourable to his love of his own people, from the stern argument of the former chapter.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Brethren, my heart's desire...that in which the heart would experience full satisfaction.
Desire and prayer for their salvation.
Albert Barnes: My heart’s desire - The word 'desire' εὐδοκία eudokia means benevolence, and the expression, 'my heart’s desire,' means my earnest and sincere wish.

Prayer to God - He not only cherished this feeling but he expressed it in a desire to God. He had no desire that his kinsmen should be destroyed; no pleasure in the appalling doctrine which he had been defending. He still wished their welfare; and could still pray for them that they might return to God.
So should the awful doctrines of religion be preached by all the ambassadors of God.
Marvin Vincent: Brethren. See on 1 John 2:9. An expression of affectionate interest and indicating emotion.
My heart's desire [η ευδοκια της εμης καρδιας]. More literally, the good will of my heart. See on Luke 2:14.
For Israel. The best texts substitute aujtwn for them; those described in the last three verses of ch. 9. Bengel remarks that Paul would not have prayed had they been utterly reprobate.
John Calvin: We here see with what solicitude the holy man obviated offenses.
It may be at the same time that he was also induced by another reason to testify his love towards the nation from which he had sprung.

At the beginning of the last chapter the Apostle expressed his great grief for his brethren the Jews, he now expresses his great love towards them, and his strong desire for their highest good — their salvation.
Philip Schaff: The salvation of Israel was the ideal of his heart.
The correct reading shows the intimate connection of thought with the close of chap. 9.
Their salvation is the end (ideal) of his 'good pleasure,' and this he asks God to grant.
Archibald T. Robertson: Desire (ευδοκια)... It means will, pleasure, satisfaction.
Supplication (δεησις). Late word from δεομα, to want, to beg, to pray.
Paul leaves God's problem to him and pours out his prayer for the Jews in accordance with his strong words in Romans 9:1-5.
John Gill: Brethren, my heart's desire... that they might be saved.
he continually bore them upon his mind at the throne of grace
he knew there was a seed, a remnant according to the election of grace, at that present time among them, that should be saved
John Wesley: My prayer to God is, that they may be saved — He would not have prayed for this, had they been absolutely reprobated.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Apostle Paul, after presenting a stern argument in the previous chapter, now addresses the Romans affectionately as brethren and reveals his genuine concern for the salvation of Israel. He expresses his heartfelt desire and offers supplication to God on their behalf. Paul's intention is to refute any negative impressions others may have had about his love for his own people, emphasizing that his desire and prayer for their salvation stem from the goodwill and satisfaction of his heart. He earnestly prays for the highest good of his kinsmen, desiring their deliverance and showing his unwavering commitment to intercede for them before God's throne of grace.

After passionately arguing his point in the previous chapter, Paul now addresses his readers as brethren and expresses his strong affection and desire for the salvation of Israel. Despite the severity of his previous argument, he wants to dispel any doubts about his love for his own people. His heartfelt prayer and supplication to God on their behalf demonstrate the genuine goodwill and satisfaction of his heart. Paul's unwavering commitment to intercede for the salvation of his kinsmen is evident as he continually lifts them up in prayer before the throne of grace.

In Romans 10:1, Paul, having made a stern argument in the previous chapter, now addresses the Romans affectionately as brethren and expresses his genuine concern for the salvation of Israel. He fervently desires their deliverance and offers supplication to God on their behalf. Paul's intention is to refute any negative impressions others may have had about his love for his own people and emphasizes his unwavering commitment to intercede for them. His heartfelt prayers reflect the goodwill and satisfaction of his heart.

The Apostle Paul, after presenting a stern argument, now addresses the Romans affectionately as brethren and reveals his genuine desire and supplication to God for the salvation of Israel. His strong words in the previous chapter did not diminish his love for his own people, but rather fueled his earnest prayers on their behalf. Paul's unwavering commitment to intercede for their highest good and his heartfelt satisfaction in seeing them saved shine through his words of affectionate interest and emotional connection.

In his address to the Romans, Paul affectionately calls them brethren after his stern argument in the previous chapter. He expresses his deep desire and supplication to God on behalf of Israel, demonstrating his unwavering love for his own people. Despite the severity of his previous points, Paul's heartfelt prayers reflect the satisfaction and goodwill of his heart. His strong words in Romans 9:1-5 fuel his commitment to continuously intercede for the salvation of the Jews, leaving God's ultimate decision in His hands.
